definition: variant of 人[ren2]/"person" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 10), occurring in 兒, 兀, 兄 etc
to regard sth as a plaything (idiom); to consider unimportant/to view as trifling

sentences.english: My employer treated our request as a joke.
sentences.chinese: 我的老板把我们的要求视为儿戏。

sentences.english: Our employer treated our suggestions as a joke.
sentences.chinese: 我们的雇主把我们的建议视为儿戏。

sentences.english: They are another example of the futility of marriage between big stars in Tinseltown.
sentences.chinese: 他们再次证明了好莱坞大明星们视婚姻如儿戏。

sentences.english: There are climbing high line want back wages, it really is just a joke?
sentences.chinese: 还有爬高压线想要回工钱，难道真的仅是一场儿戏？

sentences.english: Event of lifelong significance, usually refers to marriage.
sentences.chinese: 这可是他的终身大事，不可儿戏。

sentences.english: Personal grudges and family feuds continue to make playthings of issues.
sentences.chinese: 由于个人嫌隙与家庭仇恨，国家大事被视同儿戏。

sentences.english: He wielded his pen almost as if it were a toy.
sentences.chinese: 他挥动如椽之笔，如同儿戏一般。

sentences.english: It is more like a children's game than a real issue of life and death.
sentences.chinese: 这与其说是真正的生死搏斗，不如说更象一场儿戏。

definition: to regard sth as a plaything (idiom); to consider unimportant/to view as trifling
to let emotions affect one's decisions
to act arbitrarily regardless of the rules/to mess with sth/to make a hash of things/to cause trouble
to take seriously (often with negative expression: "don't take it too seriously")/to treat conscientiously
to make a big fuss over a minor issue (idiom)
vitally important/a matter of life and death
old: to reap the consequences of one's words (idiom, from Mencius); modern: to go back on one's word/to blow hot and cold/to contradict oneself/inconsistent
variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
to be the most ridiculous thing in the world (idiom)
pinyin: hua2 tian1 xia4 zhi1 da4 ji1
